section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Collect any measuring tools you have in the classroom such as a digital or balance scale, measuring cups, timers, and thermometers.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Whose Hands Are These? today, we talked about people who help in the community. We also learned about some of the measuring tools they use for their jobs.

In this matching activity, you will turn over two cards. Say the name of the measuring tool and what it measures. If it’s a match, you keep the cards. If it’s not a match, turn them over and it will be the next friend’s turn to play.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Before beginning the activity, flip through the cards to teach the name of each measuring tool and explain its purpose. If you have an example of that tool, pass it around to each child.

Ask Place Activity Cards face-down on the table. Have children take turns picking and turning over two cards. Ask, What is this tool called? What does it measure? If a child turns over two of the same tools, guide the child to keep both cards. If the tools do not match, guide the child to turn both cards over again.
Repeat Continue the activity until all children have had multiple turns.
Talk About Tools Look through the cards one more time and ask, Which community helper might use this tool? What can you measure with this tool?
Complete the activity with the cards face up rather than face down. Removing the memory challenge allows children to focus just on learning about the tools and their uses.

Have children identify another tool that measures the same attribute as their Activity Cards. For example, if a child found the match for the balance scales, that child could name a produce scale or bathroom scale as another example of a tool that measures weight.
For children who need additional language support, present each tool using these sentence frames: This is a . It measures . Encourage children to use these frames each time they name a tool.
Fine motor skills can be supported by having children take turns arranging the cards in a face-up or face-down grid on the table. They can practice placing the cards precisely in position.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Gather pairs of objects from around the classroom with clearly different attributes: a very light object and a very heavy object; a very small object and a very tall object; a very short object and a very long object.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Whose Hands Are These?, we talked about people who measure very large things, like architects, and people who measure smaller things, like potters.
In this activity, you will compare the sizes of many different objects. You’ll tell me which object is heavier, which object is taller, and which object is longer.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show children one light object and one heavy object. Ask: Which is heavier? Have children hold the objects to compare. Then, guide them to point to the heavier object.

Repeat Continue the activity with the other four objects, showing children small and tall objects and short and long objects to compare. Each time, suggest children hold the objects to check which is taller or longer before giving their answer.

Extend After children have identified the heavier, taller, and longer objects, ask them to find their own pair of objects to compare: Find two objects in the classroom that you want to compare, and bring them back here. Have children compare their objects using comparison language.
Talk About It Guide children to discuss how they made their conclusions. How did you know which object is heavier? Taller? Longer? What tool can you use to measure exactly how tall an object is?

Demonstrate comparing items. For weight, hold one item in each hand and say which feels heavier. For height, place the items next to each other and hold your hand at the top of each. For length, line up both objects at the same starting line and say which is longer.
Give children three or more objects to order by weight, height, or length. Have children explain how they knew in which order the objects should be placed.
For children who may need more language support, explain that the suffix -er at the end of a word shows a comparison. It is like saying “more.”

Create a separate space for comparing objects, using manila folders as walls. Have children come one by one to the space and privately compare the objects, pointing individually to the object that is heavier, taller, or longer.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need about 20 Pattern Blocks for each child. Each child should have a mix of shapes.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Whose Hands Are These?, we talked about people who help in the community. One of those people was an architect. Who remembers what an architect does?
In this activity, you will be an architect. You will use Pattern Blocks to make a building.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Build! Give each child a pile of Pattern Blocks. Guide them to use the blocks to build a building. Get creative! Make any kind of building you want. Will it be tall? Will it be wide?
Ask As children work, ask questions about the Pattern Blocks they are using. What shape are you holding? Where is it going to go? How can you turn it? If you flip it, will it fit better?

Talk About Shapes Have children briefly show and describe their buildings. All of these buildings are beautiful! Then, discuss the shapes they used. Who used a triangle in their building? So many of you used triangles! But you flipped and turned them to make something unique. Even though these triangles are used very differently, are they all still triangles? How can you tell?

Model how to create an image of a building out of Pattern Blocks. As you work, talk aloud about the shapes you are using and how you are placing them: I am going to use a triangle for a window. I am going to turn the triangle on its side, like this.
Challenge children to build their building using only one type of Pattern Block. How can you make a roof, windows, and walls using only triangles?
Review shape vocabulary before beginning the activity, particularly square and triangle. Use sentence clozes to help children describe their shapes as necessary:

Ask children to move Pattern Blocks in a dramatic manner to see whether the shape stays the same. For example, children can hold them high above their heads, hold them while jumping three times, or carry them as they walk around the table.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need about 20 Pattern Blocks for each child. Each child should have a mix of shapes.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Super Jobs! we talked about people who help in the community. One of those people is a baker.
In this activity, you will all be bakers! We will make a cake together by stacking layers of different shapes. Then, you will each make your own shape cake.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Give each child a pile of Pattern Blocks. These shapes will be the layers of our cake. We’ll build a cake together.

First Layer Tell children what the first layer of the cake will be: Our first layer will be triangles. We’ll need one triangle from each of you! Guide children to slide a triangle into the center of the table.

Second Layer Tell children what the second layer of the cake will be: The second layer will be squares. Everyone put one square on top of the triangle layer! Guide children to place squares on top of triangles.
Repeat Continue to ask for shapes, building each “layer” of the cake until children have run out of blocks or the “cake” cannot be stacked higher without falling.
Bake Your Own When the class cake is finished, return children’s Pattern Blocks and repeat the activity, this time having children build their own individual cakes using one shape per layer.

Discuss Congratulate children on being great bakers. Then, discuss what it was like to make a shape cake: What did you have to do to the Pattern Blocks to get them to fit? Did moving them change their shape?

Limit the Pattern Blocks to only squares and triangles. Model how to build a cake, thinking aloud as you build: This is going to be a triangle layer. I’m going to add this shape. I know it’s a triangle because it has three sides and three corners.
Have children make a two-dimensional image of a cake and challenge them to use as many different shapes of Pattern Blocks as possible to create it.
Review key vocabulary before starting the activity, such as baker, cake, and layer, along with the shape names of each Pattern Block. If possible, show a picture of a layered cake.

Have children use tweezers to stack each shape in the shape cake. You may also have children use only one or two Pattern Block per layer as they build their own cakes, increasing the precision they will need while stacking to keep their cakes standing.
